passage: “The bad guy in the story—the western corn  45 rootworm—was actually part of a multi-species  conspiracy,” says Joe Spencer, who was part of the  study.  The team, including graduate student Chia-Ching  Chu, found that a third of the rootworms’ gut  50 bacteria comprise species that are unique to either  the resistant or normal varieties. These two factions  also differ in the relative numbers of the bacteria that  they share.  These different microbes give the resistant beetles  55 an edge when eating soybeans. The rootworms digest  the protein in their meals using enzymes called  cysteine proteases, and soybeans defend themselves  with substances that can block these enzymes.  But Chu found that the more the beetles’ bacteria  60 differed from the normal set, the higher the levels of  cysteine proteases in their guts. By avoiding  indigestion, these beetles were better at surviving  among soybeans, and more likely to lay their eggs  there.  65  The team proved that the bacteria were  responsible by killing them with antibiotics. Sure  enough, this drastically lowered the cysteine protease  activity in the guts of the rotation-resistant beetles  and wrecked their ability to thrive among soybeans.

questions.description: Over the course of the passage, the main focus  shifts from a

options.description: statement about the challenge posed by a particular insect to an indication of why that challenge was easy to overcome.
summary of a once-unexplained natural phenomenon to a biography of the scientists who researched that phenomenon.
description of a problem affecting agriculture to an explanation of how scientists identified the cause of that problem.
discussion about a scientific field to an anecdote showing how research is done in that field.

questions.description: The statement “zoology is ecology” (line 6) mainly  serves to

options.description: propose that two areas of scientific knowledge be merged.
point out that knowledge obtained in one field of research will lead to expertise in another.
assert a point about biological science that is supported by the example in the passage.
suggest that one field of scientific research has completely supplanted another.

questions.description: According to the passage, one similarity between  rotation-resistant rootworms and normal rootworms  is that they both

options.description: reduce crop productivity by extracting nutrients from the soil.
produce larvae that feed on the plant roots of crops.
adapt to crop rotation by maintaining high levels of enzymes in their guts.
contain the same quantity and composition of bacteria in their guts.

questions.description: Which choice most clearly provides information   indicating how some rootworms have overcome   farmers’ efforts to eradicate them?

options.description: Lines 15-17 (“These . . .   die”)
Lines 18-20 (“But . . .   corn”)
Lines 25-28 (“Researchers . . .   question”)
Lines 41-43 (“And . . .   rotation”)

questions.description: The central claim in the fourth paragraph  (lines 23-35) is that

options.description: extensive study of the rootworm’s genes was insufficient to determine why some rootworms  are rotation resistant.
the rootworm’s ability to adapt to pest control methods is unique among insects.
the genetic profile of rootworms is significantly more complex than researchers initially believed.
our current understanding of genetics is inadequate to allow researchers to understand  why some rootworms are rotation resistant.

questions.description: As used in line 24, “separate” most nearly means

options.description: distinguish.
discharge.
extract.
scatter.

questions.description: According to the passage, the gut bacteria of  rotation-resistant rootworms

options.description: help the rootworms survive in soybean crops.
are responsible for lowering the amount of cysteine protease in the rootworms’ guts.
make the rootworms less vulnerable to being killed by antibiotics.
are transferred to the larvae that hatch from the rootworms’ eggs.

questions.description: Which choice provides the best evidence for the   answer to the previous question?

Lines 39-40 (“The rotation-resistant . . .   ones”)
Lines 44-47 (“The bad . . .   study”)
Lines 54-55 (“These . . .   soybeans”)

questions.description: The main idea of the last paragraph is that

options.description: cysteine proteases are harmful to rootworms when present in large quantities in the body.
eggs laid by rotation-resistant rootworms will hatch into crops of soybeans.
bacteria unique to rotation-resistant rootworms allow them to digest soybeans.
rotation-resistant rootworms do not digest soybeans using cysteine proteases.
